headers: DRAFT PROSPECTS - PERSONALITY & BASELINE METRICS SYSTEM

rows.DRAFT PROSPECTS - PERSONALITY & BASELINE: Comprehensive personality, physical, and technical metrics for 352 draft prospects.
All metrics are SEEDED for deterministic generation and scout bias application.
Description: Pre-snap reads, situational football IQ, recognition speed
- "Football IQ Obsessed" scouts overweight this +10 points
- Film study reveals awareness in disguise recognition
- 90+ Awareness: Peyton Manning type, changes plays at line
- 75-85: Solid NFL starter, makes correct reads
- 60-70: Needs simple scheme, struggles with adjustments
- <60: Lost in complex defenses, slow processor
Description: Composure under pressure, handles adversity, big moment performance
Observable Via: Film Study (clutch situations), Interview
- "Character First" scouts heavily weight low poise as red flag
- Film study shows 4th quarter performance, blowout behavior
- 90+ Poise: Ice in veins, performs in playoffs/prime time
- <60: Crumbles in big moments, emotional fragility
Description: Concentration, attention to detail, assignment discipline
Observable Via: Film Study, Coach References
- C/QB slightly higher (69-70) due to pre-snap responsibilities
- Film grinders see missed assignments, mental errors
- Coaches reveal study habits, meeting room attentiveness
- 90+ Focus: Robotic consistency, never out of position
- <60: Constant mental errors, plays out of control
Description: Commands respect, vocal/lead by example, elevates teammates
Observable Via: Interview, Team References, Captain status
- "Leadership Premium" scouts add +8 to grade for high leadership
- Team captain status = instant +5 perceived leadership
- Interview reveals vocal presence vs. quiet worker
- 90+ Leadership: Locker room commander, Ray Lewis type
- 70-79: Lead by example, earns respect through work
Description: Competitive fire, hates losing, plays through pain, alpha mentality
Observable Via: Film Study (motor), Interview, Background Check
- Film shows effort plays, fighting for extra yards
- Too high + low poise = "Emotional Player" flag
- 90+ Competitiveness: Refuses to lose, alpha dog, Michael Jordan
- 60-69: Plays hard but lacks killer instinct
Description: Self-belief, swagger, not easily rattled, takes criticism constructively
- Interview reveals arrogance vs. confidence line
- Workout shows how they respond to poor reps
Description: Film study habits, gym rat, extra work, improvement trajectory
- Coach references give hints but can lie/exaggerate
- College improvement trajectory suggests work ethic
- 90+ Work Ethic: First in, last out, film junkie, Jerry Rice
- <60: Lazy, coasts on talent, Vernon Gholston risk
Character Flag: Work_Ethic <60 → 25% chance "Work Ethic Question" flag
Description: Takes coaching, adapts technique, ego in check, learns system
- Coach references critical (but can be biased)
- Interview reveals ego, willingness to learn
- 90+ Coachability: Sponge, adapts immediately, no ego
- <60: Unteachable, ego problem, set in ways
Description: Understand schemes, adjustments, chess not checkers, study film
Observable Via: Film Study, Interview (whiteboard test), Wonderlic proxy
- "Analytics Guru" scouts trust measurable IQ tests
- Film study shows disguise recognition, adjustments
- 90+ Football IQ: Savant, understands all schemes
- 75-85: Smart player, picks up systems quickly
Description: Natural feel, anticipation, see play develop, sixth sense
Observable Via: Film Study (harder to quantify)
- Film grinders love instincts (see it or don't)
- 90+ Instincts: Ball magnet, always in right place
- 60-70: Reactive, needs to see it to react
- <60: Always a step late, poor feel
Description: Handles success/failure, off-field choices, NFL-ready mindset
- Background checks reveal arrest history, interviews
- Age factor: Older players perceived as more mature
- 90+ Maturity: Old soul, professional, beyond years
- <60: Immature, red flags, Laremy Tunsil risk
Description: Relentless effort, plays through whistle, hustle, doesn't take plays off
- Slightly higher for pass rushers (hustle matters)
- Film grinders love high motor players
- 90+ Motor: Never stops, chases down plays, JJ Watt
These correlate with combine measurables but represent baseline athletic ability.
Description: First step quickness, 0-10 yards, explosion off line
Description: Change of direction, short-area quickness, lateral movement
Description: Functional strength, power at point of attack
Observable Via: Combine (bench press proxy), Film
Note: NOT just bench press reps
Description: Explosiveness, lower body power, high-point ability
Description: Conditioning, 4th quarter performance, snap count capacity
Observable Via: Film (late game), Coach References
Each position has 6 key technical skills rated 50-99.
- Touch: Finesse throws, back shoulder, lobs
- Vision: See holes, cutback lanes, patience
- Balance: Contact balance, stay on feet
- Elusiveness: Make defenders miss, jump cuts
- Release: Beat press, get off line
- Release: Get off line vs LBs
- Anchor: Base, strength at point of attack
- Run_Blocking: Power at point of attack
- Anchor: Hold ground vs bull rush
- Leverage: Pad level, get under OL
- Pass_Rush: Get to QB, rush moves
- Coverage: Drop to zones, match routes
- Zone_Coverage: Read QB, break on ball
Based on personality metrics, prospects may receive character flags:
- All personality metrics in acceptable range
- Example: Coaches hint at inconsistent effort
- Ignores physical traits if IQ low
- Additional context: No arrests, clean record
Every metric has a corresponding seed for deterministic generation:
3. Use integer to seed random generator
- Start with position baseline (60-76 depending on metric/position)
- Add draft tier modifier (+5 for Top 5, -5 for UDFA)
The personality/baseline metrics INFORM but don't DETERMINE the overall seeds:
Concerns: "Emotional Player flag, low poise, not a leader"
YOUR EVALUATION: 85 (uncertain due to character flag)
- Emotional player flag was real but manageable
- Work ethic (68) kept him from reaching full potential (91) early
- Scouts B & C were closer than Scout A
User: "I want to scout John Calvin. Activities: Film study (3 games),
Interview, Background check. Use Scout A (character first) and
ChatGPT: [Reads seeds, applies observable rules, applies biases]
- Motor: 87 - Plays through whistle, chases down plays
- Competitiveness: 89 - Fights for extra yards, alpha mentality
- Hands: 78 - Some concentration drops on film
rows.col_3: Speed, Acceleration, Agility, Strength, Jumping, Stamina
Correlate with combine measurables but represent deeper athleticism

rows.DRAFT PROSPECTS - PERSONALITY & BASELINE: - Awareness: 78 - Passed whiteboard test, understands coverage
- Leadership: 65 - Not overly vocal, leads by example
rows.col_3: QB: Accuracy, Arm_Strength, Touch, Mechanics, Pocket_Presence, Release

rows.DRAFT PROSPECTS - PERSONALITY & BASELINE: - Confidence: 84 - Swagger present, believes in abilities
rows.col_3: WR: Route_Running, Hands, Release, YAC_Ability, Body_Control, Contested_Catch

rows.DRAFT PROSPECTS - PERSONALITY & BASELINE: - Poise: 63 - Seemed nervous, emotional in discussion
rows.col_3: EDGE: Pass_Rush, Run_Defense, Hand_Technique, Bend, Speed_to_Power, Pursuit
CB: Man_Coverage, Zone_Coverage, Press_Technique, Ball_Skills, Tackling, Backpedal

rows.DRAFT PROSPECTS - PERSONALITY & BASELINE: - Explanation: Competitive fire (89) + lower poise (63) = volatility risk
- Coach reference: "Great competitor, can be emotional"

rows.col_3: Every metric has a unique seed: {Metric}_{PlayerName}_{PlayerID}
Deterministic generation (same seed = same value always)

rows.DRAFT PROSPECTS - PERSONALITY & BASELINE:
The 'Emotional Player' flag concerns me. Poise (63) is below average _x000D_
for a top pick. Not a natural leader (65). Elite physical tools but _x000D_
character makeup worries me. Could be a headcase.
rows.col_3: Prevents cheating while allowing ChatGPT to decode

rows.DRAFT PROSPECTS - PERSONALITY & BASELINE:
Elite competitiveness (89) and motor (87). This is a winner. The _x000D_
emotional label is overblown - it's just competitive fire. Physical _x000D_
tools are generational. He's my WR1.
rows.col_3: QBs have higher Awareness (75 baseline) than HBs (68)
Centers have higher Leadership (75) than CBs (63)

rows.DRAFT PROSPECTS - PERSONALITY & BASELINE: Your Decision: Average to 80? Trust Scout A? Trust Scout B?
rows.col_3: EDGE rushers have higher Competitiveness (76) than OGs (71)
Emotional Player: 1 prospect (0.3%) - High Competitiveness + Low Poise
"Emotional player flag is a red flag. Low poise concerns me. Can't trust him in big moments."
"Elite competitiveness and motor. This is a winner. Poise will come with experience."
"Measurables are generational. 6'5", 4.38, 42" vert. Character is overblown."
Your consensus: 85 (wide range, uncertain) Truth: 89 (Scout B closest!)
True Work_Ethic (you can't see film study habits)
